page.title: 07NW Derby, Local History
page.content: In 1220, in the reign of Henry III, a new kind of monk appeared in Derby Market Place; dressed in a black cloak with a bowl hanging at the girdle, talking in the ordinary language of the people. He was a friar, a follower of St. Dominic. The friars went into Derby and surrounding villages preaching and tending the sick. They lived by begging, owning nothing themselves, but serving only God and the people. They probably preached at the Headless Cross on Ashbourne Road and brought the Word of God to the ordinary people of Derby. The Black Friars built a friary in what is now Friargate (Freregate 1342) where the Friary Hotel now stands. This along with other religious houses was dissolved by Henry VIII in 1534/5. The friars had worked in Derby for over 300 years.
